docs.lead_paragraph: In a final blur of vote counting and deal making, Congressional negotiators raced on Wednesday to finish sweeping Medicare legislation, hoping to send it to the full House and Senate by week's end. But Democratic leaders mounted a furious new attack on the measure, assailing the endorsement by AARP on Monday as a betrayal of the organization's members and as a capitulation to the Republicans. Republican leaders continued to express confidence that the $400 billion bill was headed for final passage, but they also spent much of the day counting heads, adjusting the legislation to secure additional votes and making the case for the biggest overhaul of Medicare since its creation. ''It's coming, a vote at a time,'' said J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, the speaker of the House.

headline.main: Counting Votes and Attacks In Final Push for Medicare Bill

docs.abstract: Congressional negotiators race to finish sweeping Medicare legislation, hoping to send it to full House and Senate by week's end; Democratic leaders mount furious new attack on measure, assailing endorsement by AARP as betrayal of organization's members and as capitulation to Republicans; in House, pivotal votes are clearly Republican conservatives, who are dismayed at prospect of expanding entitlement program they already consider unsustainable; Republican leaders seek to shore up their support by bringing back Newt Gingrich, former House speaker, to argue for bill in closed-door caucus; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In a final blur of vote counting and deal making, Congressional negotiators raced on Wednesday to finish sweeping Medicare legislation, hoping to send it to the full House and Senate by week's end. But Democratic leaders mounted a furious new attack...

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and ROBIN TONER

docs.lead_paragraph: Days after President John F. Kennedy and Lee Harvey Oswald were gunned down in this city in November 1963, Brig. Gen. Herbert A. Hall, retired in Tucson, folded a large, beribboned certificate into an envelope and mailed it to the mayor of Dallas, Earle Cabell. Over the words ''Honorary Citizen of Dallas'' -- a title given to him by city fathers during the Korean War days of 1951 -- General Hall had defiantly scrawled these words: ''Returned with shame and sorrow.''

headline.main: Dallas Comes to Terms With the Day That Defined It

docs.abstract: Pres John F Kennedy's assassination shocked world but shamed Dallas, where it occurred; city immediately felt sting of nation's revulsion; it was scorned as nest of right-wing bigots and Kennedy haters, and even branded as somehow complicit in president's death; now, as nation prepares for observance of 40th anniversary of event, a different Dallas has moved to forefront of remembrances; Dallas is willingly, energetically, even protectively, taking note of its harsh but inexorable place in history; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Suffolk County faces a potential $200 million deficit in 2005, the incoming county executive warned on Tuesday, adding that he will ''hit the ground running'' to prevent a shortfall. The county executive-elect, Steve Levy, made the comments as he outlined his vision for Suffolk at a news conference and a lunch. He addressed a number of issues, including corruption, housing, police costs and cooperation with adjacent Nassau County.

headline.main: Executive-Elect Vows to Cut Suffolk's Expenses

docs.abstract: Suffolk County (NY) Executive-elect Steve Levy says he will cut county's expenses to avoid $200 million deficit in 2005 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With senators and representatives back in the Capitol for the first time since negotiators agreed on legislation to overhaul Medicare last weekend, supporters of the measure expressed confidence on Tuesday that it would be passed within a week. At the same time, some opponents raised doubts about whether they had enough votes to block the bill. ''Are we going to be home for Thanksgiving with everything completed?'' asked Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the Republican leader. ''The answer is yes.''

headline.main: Medicare Bill Supporters Confident of Passage

docs.abstract: Sen Bill Frist and other supporters of bill to overhaul Medicare predict Congress will approve bill; Bush administration and bill's sponsors scramble to shore up support from conservative Republicans who fear bill does too little to transform program and from moderates in both parties, who fear threat to program; cite endorsement by AARP; Vice Pres Dick Cheney and Health Sec Tommy G Thompson meet with Republican senators; Sens Edward M Kennedy and Debbie Stabenow score bill, meeting of Democratic senators; Sens Max Baucus and John B Breaux, Democrats who helped write bill, defend it; some opponents raise doubts about whether they can block bill, which would provide prescription drug coverage and give private health plans much larger role in Medicare; some AARP members question endorsement; House, 237-176, reaffirms its support for bill to allow imports of low-cost prescription drugs from Canada and Europe (M)
docs.snippet: With senators and representatives back in the Capitol for the first time since negotiators agreed on legislation to overhaul Medicare last weekend, supporters of the measure expressed confidence on Tuesday that it would be passed within a week. At...

byline.original: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM and ROBERT PEAR; Robin Toner contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Six of the Democratic presidential candidates mounted a heated attack on the new Medicare bill on Tuesday at a forum sponsored by AARP. The contenders denounced the plan to provide drug benefits to the elderly as a Republican-led effort to privatize and undermine the federal insurance program. Several hopefuls sharply criticized AARP, the powerful lobbying group for older Americans, for endorsing the bill on Monday. Hundreds of the elderly in the audience here applauded the criticism.
docs.abstract: Democratic presidential rivals Wesley K Clark, Howard Dean, Rep Richard A Gephardt and Sens John Kerry, John Edwards and Joseph I Lieberman score new bill to provide prescription drug benefits under Medicare as Republican-led effort to privatize and undermine program, AARP-sponsored forum, Bedford, NH; several sharply criticize AARP for endorsing bill, criticism applauded by hundreds of elderly in audience; AARP displays at forum television ad that is part of its $7 million drive for bill (M)
docs.snippet: Six of the Democratic presidential candidates mounted a heated attack on the new Medicare bill on Tuesday at a forum sponsored by AARP. The contenders denounced the plan to provide drug benefits to the elderly as a Republican-led effort to privatize...

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite its shortcomings, the Medicare prescription drug bill heading for a vote in Congress is worthy of passage. Fears that the legislation contains seeds that will ultimately destroy the traditional Medicare program strike us as overblown. Our own chief qualm is that the country, with deficits looming as far as prognosticators can see, cannot afford a program that will cost, at a minimum, $400 billion over 10 years. Millions of middle-income Americans will get only modest help from the program, and they will have to cope with a crazy-quilt pattern of benefits. But fortunately, the bill is strongest when it comes to the most important target groups: elderly people with low incomes or very high drug bills.
docs.abstract: Editorial backs Medicare prescription drug bill despite its shortcomings; notes bill is at its strongest in aiding elderly with low incomes or very high drug bills; calls overblown fears that bill will ultimately destroy traditional Medicare program; expresses concern about $400 billion cost of program over 10 years; urges rescinding tax cuts for wealthy to pay for drug benefit
docs.snippet: Despite its shortcomings, the Medicare prescription drug bill heading for a vote in Congress is worthy of passage. Fears that the legislation contains seeds that will ultimately destroy the traditional Medicare program strike us as overblown. Our own...

docs.lead_paragraph: The president of the medical staff at Christ Hospital, Dr. George Ciechanowski, has been removed from the prestigious elective position by colleagues who oppose a government plan for malpractice insurance reform, which he favors. Dr. Ciechanowski confirmed yesterday that at a Monday night meeting, colleagues voted to remove him. In June, thousands of doctors staged a demonstration protesting what they regard as ruinously high premiums for needed malpractice insurance. Dr. Ciechanowski, who remains the hospital's chief of pulmonary and critical care, publicly supported the state's plan to subsidize malpractice insurance to reduce premiums. Other doctors favor limiting jury awards in malpractice cases. Stacy Albin (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: Doctor Ousted In Dispute

docs.abstract: Dr George Ciechanowski is removed from elective position of president at Christ Hospital in Jersey City by colleagues who oppose New Jersey's plan to subsidize malpractice insurance, which he favors (S)

byline.original: By Stacy Albin (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

docs.lead_paragraph: IT sounds like a marketer's dream -- a flu vaccine that is given through a spray in the nose rather than an often painful shot in the arm. But attempts to sell such a vaccine this flu season have turned into a nightmare. Despite a short but costly advertising campaign, sales of the nasal spray flu vaccine, known as FluMist, have fallen startlingly short of projections.

headline.main: Anatomy of a failed product introduction: How a nasal spray flu vaccine flopped in the marketplace.

docs.abstract: Article on how nasal spray influenza vaccine FluMist manufactured by MedImmune and co-marketed by Wyeth flopped in marketplace (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Transit mechanics tentatively agreed to end a strike that has idled the Los Angeles public transportation system, the nation's third largest, for more than a month, the two sides said. The deal includes a 6 percent raise over three years, a person close to the negotiations said. Negotiations over the weekend settled all of the contract issues except the biggest, health benefits, which will be resolved through nonbinding arbitration.

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Agreement In Transit Strike

docs.abstract: Mechanics end month-long strike that has idled transit systems in Los Angeles, agreeing to 6 percent raise over three years and resolution of health benefit issues through non-binding arbitration (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The day of reckoning for Dr. Diane E. Meier, a geriatrician at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, came a decade ago when she encountered a 73-year-old man with terminal lung cancer. His hands and feet were tied to the bed because he repeatedly pulled out the feeding tube inserted through his nose, despite his explicit wish that he receive no treatment. ''What's going on here?'' Dr. Meier asked the resident on duty. ''This man is dying. Why is he tied to the bed?''

headline.main: SCIENTIST AT WORK/Diane Meier; Providing Care, When the Cure Is Out of Reach

docs.abstract: Lilian and Benjamin Hertzberg Palliative Care Institute at Mount Sinai Medical Center, directed by geriatrician Dr Diane E Meier, strives to take care of those patients dealing with physical and emotional suffering by offering solutions to improve quality of life and not necessarily to provide treatment to cure patients; estimated 1,500 hospitals have palliative care department compared with just 100 five years ago; financial constraints are shown to be primary stumbling block to continued growth; article calls for change in medical philosophy that would uncouple palliative care from terminal illness and provide for patients of all ages with all types of medical concerns; photo (S)
